posts.title: ðŸ‡¨ðŸ‡´ðŸ‡ªðŸ‡¹ Fine City Blend from ðŸ‡¬ðŸ‡§ Strangers
posts.excerpt: A birthday gift from my friend Jordan brought from the UK, this blend of espresso-roasted coffee was absolutely delicious when we prepared our AeroPress fakespresso.

content.value: Jordan brought this from his hometown, Norwich, where
Strangers Coffee Company

roasts and brews and improves the British coffee scene. I haven't visited yet, but it's definitely on my list now - they also have nice merch and easy brew guides on their website. This particular coffee is their award-winning Fine City Blend of American and African beans.

It includes Colombian and Ethiopian coffee of Caturra and Heirloom varieties from around 2000 MASL, mixing washed and natural processing. The official flavour profile states red berries, chocolate, and orange citrus, and especially the red berries with chocolate were very nice and strong there.

We almost exclusively used this Fine City Blend to prepare our "fakespresso" in AeroPress, using our favorite recipe from the Aeromatic app by Tim Wendelboe, producing a stronger cup of coffee (apparently similar to a moka pot). It's an easy recipe, with my Q2 grinder set at 1.0.2 for 20g of coffee, topped with 125 of boiling water, stirred 3 times and immediately pressed. It was really surprisingly good and I enjoyed it very much.

posts.title: ðŸ‡³ðŸ‡® Nicaragua from ðŸ‡¦ðŸ‡¹ Wiener RÃ¶sthaus
posts.excerpt: Dark, washed and more chocolatey than fruity coffee, which I got to being nice and not bitter.

content.value: Another one from a nearby classic, Winer RÃ¶sthaus. Again, I didn't have that much time to play with it, but I did note down very visually dark beans and a very fruity smell - which was a surprise since otherwise, the coffee was more on the chocolate-bitter side.

It comes from the Miraflor Esteli reserve from just 950-1350 MASL, and is a washed mix of Catuai and Caturra varietas. The official flavour profile includes almond aroma and citruses, with chocolate notes, slightly floral with full and strong finish.

I used mainly the classic V60 with a classic Hoffmann 1cup technique, and for the first time I also started measuring the temperature of the water - or rather the time after boiling. It took some tries to get to a finer grind (1.9.0 on 1zpresso Q2) and optimal 2-minute water boil time, but it became a very consistent and good 300ml cup from 18g with 2:30 minutes brew time. I would call it a success and pleasure!
I also tried it once with AeroPress, using the Blue Bottle recipe from the Aeromatic app, which resulted in a lighter, more "milky" cup I would say, definitely not bitter either.

posts.title: ðŸ‡ªðŸ‡¹ Guji Tero Farm from ðŸ‡¦ðŸ‡¹ Wiener RÃ¶sthaus
posts.excerpt: Sweet and fruity coffee which I drank during a busy month so I didn't play with it that much. I remember it being nice and consistent, though, which counts!

content.value: After the last
darker roast
I brought home for my family, I needed something more fruity and sweet, more to my liking. And to stick with my recently-discovered new favorite coffee place, the
Wiener RÃ¶sthaus
, that's where I went after returning to Vienna. After a discussion with the baristas, they recommended a new roast,
Ethiopian Guji Tero Farm,
from their own
Vienna Coffee College
, which I believe should be a slightly different roasting entity than the RÃ¶sthaus itself - or at least it is branded as such.
They rate sweetness 4

/5, body 3/5, and acidity 2/5, with flavour notes of peach, jasmine and vanilla. It comes from the Odo Shakiso District in Ethiopia, with a mixed heirloom variety from between 1800 and 2000 MASL. The cherries were dried in the sun for 15 to 20 says before being freed from the pulp
I have to admit, I had this coffee during a busy university period, so I didn't even note down anything. I remember it being very consistent and good, so I guess it did its job!

posts.title: ðŸ‡µðŸ‡ª PachaMama from ðŸ‡¦ðŸ‡¹ Wiener RÃ¶sthaus
posts.excerpt: I finally started going to a great cafÃ© close to my place and decided to buy a darker coffee specifically for my family. I chose well and we finished it in a few days.

content.value: I knew that there was an actually good, not touristy cafÃ© in Prater, very close to where I live and go every day, but I have only visited it for the first time in March this year. Yeah, I also don't really get why. Don't ask.
Wiener RÃ¶sthaus
, or Viennese Coffee Roastery, is an amazing place connected to the
Vienna Coffee College

, organising barista courses for amateurs and professionals. Because I was coming home for the Easter break, I decided to buy beans that my mom and sister would enjoy, and I with the help of the barista, I decided to go with this
Peru PachaMama
The name itself refers to the Inca goddess and the term behind Mother Earth. The beans come from a high-quality coffee-producing province
Chanchamayo
in the
JunÃ­n
region, in southeastern Peru. It was not grown that high up, in altitude between 1320 and 1720 MASL and it is a mix of the
Caturra
and
Catuai
varieties. The
SHB EP
in the coffee's full name refer to
Strictly Hard Bean
, specifying an altitude above 1350 meters, and
European Preparation
, meaning that the beans were hand sorted to remove any defects or unwanted stuff.
It is quite a
dark
roast, intended for both espresso and filter, with a full, balanced, and strong taste profile around
chocolate and almonds

, with a long-lasting aftertaste and even slightly fruity notes. Specifically, I bought it because of the darkness of the roast and the chocolate "normal coffee" notes. I personally would go for something more wild and fruity, but this was intended for my mom and sister. And I chose well!

First thing I immediately noticed was how large the beans were. Naturally, you could also tell the darker colour. Because of the roast level, the barista suggested the use of lower water temperature, around 91Â°C. Interestingly, when I played with ChatGPT, it did not pick this up and went with classic 96Â°. Anyway, I still don't understand how we got through the whole package in one week. I actually used the AI-recommended recipe for brewing multiple cups for my family, which basically included 50-75 ml increments of water with short breaks, before getting to the final 500 ml for 30g of coffee, which is what I brewed most of the time.

It was a good coffee, especially what I was hoping for when I bought this for my family. Dark, full, nothing crazy, yet still a sweet and interesting taste, where one could really feel the hint of almonds. I bought this coffee very soon after its roast date, just two days, and we basically drank it all within two weeks, which might be a bit shorter than ideal, but it still worked well. However, next time I'm getting something a bit crazier for myself.
wienerroesthaus.at
wikipedia.org
interamericancoffee.com

posts.title: ðŸ‡·ðŸ‡¼ Microlot #3 from ðŸ‡²ðŸ‡¹ Vicky Coffee
posts.excerpt: On Malta I stumbled upon a lovely local roastery. With this fruity roast, I also started experimenting with ChatGPT as my personal barista.

content.value: Before our small
Malta getaway
, I had done some research about the specialty cafÃ©s and
roasters

on the island, naturally planning to buy some beans. My idea was to buy them in the capital, Valletta, where the most cafÃ©s are located, but to my surprise, already on the second day I randomly stumbled upon a great place in Victoria, Gozo, called
Victoria Central
, home of
Vicky Coffee

, a local roastery. Thanks to the amazing staff and great tiramisu, it didn't take long to change my plans and buy coffee there. Running short on time and with some help from the baristas, I decided to go for this
Microlot #3.
Farmed in
Nyarabuye (or Nyarubuye), Rwanda
, the infamous location of the 1994 massacre between Tutsis and Hutu, it luckily tastes better than this history. However, the
Nyarubuye Washing station
, where this coffee was probably processed (although it isn't washed, but processed naturally), is closely linked to the genocide, with the founder and owner of the
Mahembe
company deciding to invest in the community by building a wet mill after the unfortunate event.
This coffee is produced by
Coffee Villages
, a group connecting over 1,200 small local farmers, focusing on providing a clean water infrastructure to the farmers as well as educational programs for women and children. Run by
Tom Bagaza
, it is a fascinating and inspiring project which I recommend checking out. Like most of the local coffees, this micro-lot is a
Red Bourbon
, grown between 1700 and 2000 MASL.
Once again, this was a coffee with a very nice and strong sweet, fruity smell. The official notes say
blackberry, pineapple, passion fruit, grapes, and orange blossoms

, suggesting a more acidic and complex flavour profile. I bought the coffee already pretty late after its roasting on the 18th of January, and continued to drink it well into 2 months after roasting, but luckily it did not seem to matter that much. I used almost only Hario V60 and I enjoyed the results.
It was also this coffee with which I started experimenting with
ChatGPT

- trying to find the right prompt combination to get an "ideal" recipe from ChatGPT-4, hopefully focusing on the full complexity of the process. It was (and still is) an interesting idea and I enjoy it. Trying it with different coffees, it does seem to correctly pick up some aspects of the rost, such as the darkness or the taste profile, suggesting some specific points like higher water temperature or faster pouring to highlight the fruity notes more. This is something I want to keep exploring and I'll be trying it with all my coffee from now.
mahembecoffee.com
pacamaracoffeelab.com
coffeevillage.rw

posts.title: ðŸ‡¨ðŸ‡º Serrano from ðŸ‡¨ðŸ‡­ Corde Coffee
posts.excerpt: Amazing cafÃ© I visited during my vacation around Geneva. I had a great coffee, delicious zucchini gingerbread and after a chat with the owner and barista I took the beans with me.

content.value: At the beginning of February, I visited my friend who's working at CERN, in Geneva, Switzerland. It was a great vacation, I got some absolutely crazy and interesting tours of CERN (I finally properly understand what they do there!) and we also did some skiing in France. On the days when he had to work, I wandered through Geneva - since it was not my first time there, I didn't have to tick off all the touristy stuff and could instead for example just chill in cafÃ©s. One of them was
Corde Coffee
, a very cute cafÃ© (with delicious pastry as well!), where I had a cup of
Cuba Serrano
, which I then also bought after a nice chat with the barista and the owner.

Unfortunately, I'm not able to trace the coffee that much, but I did discuss it with the owner who is very passionate about bringing more Cuban coffee to Geneva and is talking directly with the producer. What I figured is that the Serrano is one of the main coffee "types" in Cuba, this one was grown on the slopes of
Sierra Maestra

, a mountain range in southeast Cuba and one of the main coffee-growing locations on the island. It's a mix of two classic Arabica varieties, Typica and Bourbon, and was processed with the washed method. According to Corde Coffee, it achieved a specialty cupping score of 84.
The taste profile already suggested more of a darker roast and a "classical" coffee taste -
dark chocolate, roasted hazelnut, and cardamom

, with little acidity. I brewed it mostly with the V60 at home in Prague during my February holidays, and my mom really enjoyed this one. However, the preparation was really interesting. First of all, A LOT of ground coffee was always left in the insides of the grinder, like a really large amount. Again, I sort of expected it from the washed coffees, but this one was extreme. Also during the bloom phase, when the coffee first comes into contact with water, it really puffed up, like a dough in the oven, something I have never seen before. It was happening with every brew and it was very strange, I wasn't even able to swirl it.

I experimented a bit with the recipes later on, but this "issue" persisted. Taste-wise, however, it didn't seem to matter. It was good, the taste profile matched exactly and we would really taste the dark coffee and nuts. As I already said, my mom was a huge fan. I also managed to experiment a bit with the AeroPress "espresso-like" brews, and it was successful, with a full and aromatic taste. But now that I'm writing this, I've decided that I will really try to investigate the weird "puffing up" more.
cubacoffee.co.uk

posts.title: ðŸ‡¨ðŸ‡· Las Lajas from ðŸ‡¦ðŸ‡¹ CoffeePirates
posts.excerpt: A highly-rated roast from the first specialty coffee shop in Vienna, with beans from a famous farm in Costa Rica. A bit more sour, difficult to master but my colleague was able to brew it really well.

content.value: As I ran out of coffee again in January and I wanted to try another local roastery to discover more of "my" city, I grabbed my friend (who also needed some new coffee, would you believe it?) and we decided to try
CoffeePirates

, apparently the first third wave coffee shop and specialty roastery in the city - established in 2012. We sat down with two different espresso shots and then went to scout the roasted beans. Unfortunately, the baristas were not that helpful, I don't think they knew that much about different roasts and were not able to recommend me anything specific, so in the end I opted for this
Las Lajas.
The first thing you notice on the package is the high, 90+ cupping score (with that, a higher price). The coffee takes its name from the 60-acre farm, Finca Las Lajas, located in the
Sabanilla district of the Alajuela province in the Central Valley of Costa Rica,
a major coffee-producing area.
It is located at around 1550 MASL in volcanic soil.

Farmed and then processed in a natural way by Oscar and Francisca ChacÃ³n, who started with this method after the 2008 earthquake which disrupted the electricity and water supply, the two main varieties are
Caturra and Catuai
, Bourbon mutations bred in Brazil, with dark red or yellow pulps.

The Las Lajas micro-mill is already well-established in the coffee world. Oscar and Francisca focus primarily on honey and natural processing, but they frequently experiment with new methods as well as trialing and cultivating new varietals. This particular natural processing type is called
Alma Negra
, in which the drying starts in a greenhouse where it is also piled up at night, and then moved to the drying beds on a patio during the day.
The taste profile and expectations were set to a
medium to strong body
, with sweet acidity and flavour notes of
nougat, blueberry, cherry, and dried fig

. The roasted beans had a nice dark colour, with a "dark" fruity smell - almost like red wine, nothing too crazy or tropical. I mainly used the V60 for brewing, but this coffee proved to be really challenging. It smelled amazing every time, but the taste was rather disappointing during the first few brews. I struggled with quite fast brewing time (around 2:15) and the beginnings were always bitter, which then got better and more flavourful as it cooled down. Trial and error led me to a finer grind (1.9.0 on my Q2), but I still wasn't really satisfied.

In February I brought it with me to the office and my colleague Petr gave it a shot with his V60 method. He let it bloom in the standard way, then poured almost half of the total amount of water and swirled it significantly with a spoon, which should
highlight the fruity tones

. And I have to say that he was successful, it tasted really well, especially the nougat and blueberry. Still, I think this coffee might have been too challenging for me to master and prepare well with the not-so-great water I have available in Vienna (and perhaps the lack of skill as well).
coffeepirates.at
eclipsecoffeeroasters.com
monmouthcoffee.co.uk
neroscurocoffee.com
Petra VeselÃ¡: VelkÃ¡ kniha o kÃ¡vÄ›

posts.title: ðŸ‡ªðŸ‡¹ Dimtu Village from ðŸ‡¦ðŸ‡¹ Jonas Reindl
posts.excerpt: My first coffee from a roastery in Vienna. Also, a new method, James Hoffman's 1-cup V60 came in the right moment - finally. Very good and consistent.

content.value: I finally got to visit a specialty cafÃ© in Vienna, Austria - for my first local roast I decided to visit
Jonas Reindl

, one of the best-rated and most famous coffee roasteries in Vienna. What surprised me there was a relatively small range of coffees to choose from - only two filter roasts if I recall correctly - so I decided to try this
Dimtu Village
. Both we and the place were a bit in a rush, so sadly I didn't really get to discuss the coffee with the baristas.
Farmed and produced by
Aklilu Kassa
, a member of a family with a long coffee tradition, together with his son
Biniyam Aklilu
, this roast takes its name from the
Dimtu Coffee Washing Station
located in the highlands of
Western Guji, in the large Oromio region

, standing relatively high at 2150 MASL. Interestingly and sadly, I can't really work out if it is the father, with his Nardos Coffee exporting company, or the son with his new Gujoo Trading company, who is the main person behind this coffee. Jonas Reindl seems to be mixing the two with Aklilu Kassa as the farmer on the package, but focusing on Biniyam Aklilu on their website... Nevertheless, the family story is quite interesting, and locating the origin has been a challenge.
What can be said with fair certainty, however, is the washed processing used for these beans. They themselves come from the classic
mixed heirloom

variety, a common name for wild varieties in Ethiopia. Because of the altitude, these beans were smaller and the drying process takes a lot longer than usual, 22 to 25 days, due to the cold weather. The beans were also visibly smaller in the final roasted package.
My first impression was the strong fruity smell. The official taste profile says
tangerines, vanilla, and dried stone fruits

, together with the smell very much typical for the heirloom. Around the same time that I was starting with this coffee, James Hoffman published his new V60 1-cup technique, just in time for me, so I immediately tried it - with great success. It was my main method of preparation for this coffee and I really liked it, it was very consistent. When colder, I tasted the citruses (perhaps tangerines?). In the end, I ended up with a slightly finer grind (22 on my 1zpresso Q2) and I have been constantly amazed by how consistent the taste was. Nothing extra special, just a really good coffee with a citrusy finish.

An interesting observation which I have not yet confirmed officially, a lot of coffee powder stays on the inside of the grinder after grinding, as if the coffee was a bit wet - I assume this comes from the fact that it was processed using the washed method.
jonasreindl.at
algrano.com
Petra VeselÃ¡: VelkÃ¡ kniha o kÃ¡vÄ›

posts.title: ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¬ Masira from ðŸ‡±ðŸ‡¹ Taste Map
posts.excerpt: Great coffee that my best friend brought me from her Baltic trip. Very strong raisins taste, which I personally absolutely loved.

content.value: When my best friend and her boyfriend visited me in Vienna after I returned there for my last uni year, they were just coming back from a Baltic vacation and brought me this
Uganda Masira
from
Taste Map
, a multi-award winning roastery in Vilnius. Not having visited Lithuania yet, it was exciting to at least get a taste of their specialty coffee culture.
From
Mbale
, a city at the bottom of the slopes of
Mount Elgon

, an extinct shield volcano in Uganda, the coffee was grown by an award-winning farmer Dison Kareng and fermented naturally and anaerobically without oxygen in air-tight containers. It is a 100% Arabica, a mixture of three varieties - SL28, one of the most well-known African varieties, originated in Kenya but increasingly important in Uganda; SL14; and SL34, all three coming from the Scott Agricultural Laboratories from the 1930s, one of the main centers for coffee breeding in East Africa, established by the colonial British government in Kenya in 1922.
This was a great coffee, I really, really enjoyed it. Already in the beans, I could smell dried fruits, particularly
raisins
, which were also the main taste for me in most of the brews. The official taste profile includes them, alongside
plums, dried fruits, and berries
, finishing with "complex, juicy, aromatic, vinous", which goes hand in hand with the raisins.

It tasted the best during the first month since I got it when I mostly used a basic french press method. Later on, I think it got a bit more bitter and the dried fruit taste was not that strong, I then experiment a bit with some Hario V60 methods, variants of the basic 4:6 method, and I managed to get a bunch of last good brews with shorter pouring intervals (around 30 seconds). Nevertheless, I will always remember the first few cups, as I love raisins.
businessfocus.co.ug
neroscurocoffee.com
worldcoffeeresearch.org

posts.title: ðŸ‡¨ðŸ‡´ Lord Voldemort from ðŸ‡¨ðŸ‡¿ Beansmith.s
posts.excerpt: Washed filter coffee that we bought in the office. I didn't like that much, but it was the start of my V60 brewing and also a learning experience when I got to watch my colleague prepare it.

content.value: I spent my summer in Prague, usually in the office. Both my colleague Petr and I recently got into specialty filter coffee, so we were discussing it often, he was teaching me how to prepare the Hario V60 and together we bought and tried some interesting roasts. One of them was this one, from a Czech roastery
Beansmith.s
, called
Lord Voldemort
(apparently the farmer, Deiro Garcia, is very much a Potterhead), bought at
Kofio
This coffee comes from the
Huila
region of Colombia, said to be the place where this variety,
Pink Bourbon

- a hybrid of the Red and Yellow Bourbon, was first found. As the name suggests, the ripe cherries are pink, and the variety is quite challenging to cultivate and produce consistently. The pink genome is easily overtaken by others and the trees, therefore, have to be carefully separated from other plants.
As if that was not enough, the beans are
washed

, an interesting fermentation process that is natural for this type, done in concrete tanks for 24 hours. During the washing, the fruit layers (the skin and the mucilage around the beans) have been removed before the drying, unlike in the natural process. This should give the coffee a "cleaner" taste, focused more on the bean itself, rather than anything else in the process.
This was really an interesting coffee. The first thing you notice is the smell - very fruity. The official taste profile says
white grapes, grapefruit, and nut butter

, and the smell really hints at the (grape)fruity part. For the preparation, I used both french press and Hario V60, as this was the first coffee on which I learned the latter - and I did struggle a bit with the Hoffmann method, especially with making just one cup for myself compared with making two for me and Petr in the office.

The final coffee was usually quite sweet and tasted of nuts, but usually, I found that it smelled better than it tasted to me. I would describe the taste as "light" rather than intensive or full, but I can't say I really liked it, I didn't manage to make it in such a way I would be satisfied with it. Interesting, but confusing.
kofio.cz
gardellicoffee.com
perfectdailygrind.com
starbucksreserve.com

posts.title: ðŸ‡ªðŸ‡¹ Agaro & Jimma from ðŸ‡¨ðŸ‡¿ BALANCE coffee & wine
posts.excerpt: My first espresso roast, bought on my cycling journey from Vienna to Prague. A better espresso machine would definitely make it better, but we still enjoyed it at home during the summer.

content.value: When I cycled from Vienna to Prague at the beginning of the summer, I stayed at my friend's place one night in Znojmo, a wine town near the borders of Czechia with Austria. Her sister owns a
very nice cafÃ©

(serving a delicious breakfast!) and they recently also started roasting coffee, in cooperation with the Coffeesquare roastery nearby. Knowing that I'm coming home for the summer and I could take advantage of the coffee machines we got, I opted for an espresso roast and got recommended this
Ethiopean Agaro & Jimma
As the name suggests, it comes from the town
Agaro in the Jimma Zone, Oromia region
. This one is from a small farmer
Mustefa Abakeno

, who farms at 18 hectares of land between 2000 and 2100 MASL. Mustefa set up a wet mill to process his and his neighbors' coffee, where he also naturally processed the beans that I took home. He is also able to wash-process coffee, and, with the changes in Ethiopean regulations in the last years, he has also started selling coffee directly to buyers.
Regarding varietals, this coffee is a 100% arabica, combination of the classic Ethiopian heirloom and specifically their two
sub-varieties 74110 and 74112

, which were developed at the Jimma Agricultural Research Center for resistance to coffee berry disease. The 74 indicates their cataloging year of 1974. The trees are short with small leaves, cherries, and beans, and this makes for a delicious washed coffee.
The flavor profile is quite wide with
strawberry mousse, yellow apple, ripe fig, and milk chocolate.

More importantly, however, the coffee is quite sweet and very creamy, which is something I remember very well as well. My mom found it quite sour and didn't like it, unlike me. I wasn't able to confirm any of the taste hints, but I really enjoyed this espresso. Apparently, it scored 87 cupping score points, in the "excellent" range.
gardellicoffee.com
reframecoffee.com
reframecoffee.com
spiritanimalcoffee.com

posts.title: ðŸ‡ªðŸ‡¹ Sasaba from ðŸ‡©ðŸ‡ª Bonanza Coffee
posts.excerpt: Delicious signature coffee from a Berlin roastery which I got while visiting my friend. Still using only french press, but also upgrading my grinder to the 1Zpresso Q2.

content.value: In May I visited my friend in Berlin, Germany. Knowing that one of the goals of my trip was to buy myself some next coffee to try, she recommended
Bonanza Coffee
, a chain of cafÃ©s and roasteries in Berlin, voted best CafÃ©s and Coffee Roasteries in Germany in 2022 and also distributing to Asia with branches in South Korea.
It didn't take long to choose - I went for
Sasaba Ethiopia coffee
, medium (omni) roast, probably the most famous one from Bonanza and a winning coffee of several brewers' cups and barista championships. Coming from the
Guji region in Ethiopia
, the beans are mixed local heirloom varietals, term referring to old arabica plant varietals in Ethiopia. The coffee was naturally processed in the
Sasaba Washing Station

, founded in 2005 and owned by Tsegay Hagos Tsefaye, which collects coffee from more than 500 smallholders in the Guji region, washes or naturally processes them (depending on the coffee) and then distributes the final product. The natural coffees, as was the case with this Sasaba Ethiopia from Bonanza, usually dry for 15 to 20 days.
The story of the Sasaba Washing Station is an interesting one, and you can read more about it
here
. Tsegay Tsefaye, the founder and owner, focuses a lot on the smallholders growing the coffee - he trains them regularly and pays out premiums for outstanding quality. It is located near the town of
Bule Hora in the Goji Zone in Oromia Region
. The farms are located around there as well.
Coming to the taste profile, the Sasaba Washing Station is known for several of them, with the main one being
peach
, which is also one of the profiles of this Sasaba Ethiopia coffee. However, the most significant is
milk chocolate
, which I could really taste, and the third one is
vanilla

. I have used only french press when preparing this coffee, but this was around the time when I upgraded my grinder - to the 1Zpresso Q2, an amazing one. With that, I have really enjoyed this coffee, it is still to this day the favorite one I've had, and it tasted great - especially the strong note of milk chocolate. Next time I'm in Berlin, I know what I'm buying again.
The terms that Bonanza Coffee likes to use - Unnecessarily Good and Not Your Typical - are true.

posts.title: ðŸ‡¨ðŸ‡´ Finca PotosÃ­ from ðŸ‡¸ðŸ‡° Good Times Coffee
posts.excerpt: My very first coffee from my very first trip to Bratislava. The official start of my new hobby was a sweet omni roast from Colombia, through which I learned the french press.

content.value: Shortly after I decided to start a new hobby - coffee - in February this year, I went to Bratislava, Slovakia. I figured it would be the perfect opportunity to buy my first coffee beans. Many Google search sessions later, I decided to choose
Good Times Coffee
for my visit, a small cafÃ© and roastery with great reviews and a convenient location for my trip.

After a short discussion with the barista, where I explained how new I am to this whole coffee thing, and that I had just recently bought my first french press and grinder, she recommended this Colombian omni roast. It comes from the
Finca PotosÃ­ farm in Valle del Cuaca department in western Colombia
. The farm is situated at an altitude between 1400 and 2000 MASL and this particular coffee comes from a mix of varieties of 100% Arabica and has been dry processed.
The taste profile contains
raspberries, rhubarb, grapes, and citruses

. I really liked it, even though I'm sure it could have been prepared in a much better way than I did, considering it was my first coffee. Unfortunately, I'm also writing this up more than half a year later, so I can't say much about the coffee. I do remember I liked it, though, and I could really taste the raspberries. As hinted above, I only used a french press for this coffee.
I wanted to learn and write something more about the farm and the origins of the coffee, but unfortunately, I cannot find it anymore on the Good Times Coffee roasters' website.
